title: SHAP not equal to exact Shapley Value for ONLY two binary features?
body:
Hi Scott,

I was testing XGBoost SHAP on a simple data. (Only 2 dummy variables, Target is binary classification). Could NOT match SHAP value with exact Shapley Value. Can you shed some lights where the inconsistency came from?

- What the data looks like (Value to explain: -0.36088, feature1 = 0 AND feature2 = 1)
feature1	feature2	frequency 	log_odds
0	        0	         30,427 	    -0.33656
0	        1	         16,513 	    -0.36088
1	        0	         1,170 	    0.01878
1	        1	         477 	    -0.19547

- Base Value
E(f(x)) = Average model output = Total log_odds / Total Frequency = (30427*(-0.33656) + 16513*(-0.36088) + 1170*(0.01878) + 477*(-0.19547)) / (30427 + 16513 + 1170 + 477) = -0.3349

- Predicted Value
f(x) = f(feature1 = 0 AND feature2 = 1) = -0.36088

Shapley Value for {feature2 = 1}:

Sequence 1 - {} ==> {feature2 = 1}: S = {} (Subset), N = 2 (# of all features), |S| = 0, |S|! = 1, apply Shapley Value formula
(|S|!*(N-|S|-1)!/N!)*(v(s+{feature2=1})-v(s)) = ((1!*(2-0-1)!)/2!)*( E(f(z)|{feature2=1}) - Base Value)
= 1/2*( (Total log_odds of {feature2 = 1} / Total Frequency) - Base Value)
= 1/2*( (16513*(-0.3609)+477*(-0.1955)) / (16513+477) - (-0.3349) ) 
= 1/2*( (-0.35624) - (-0.3349) ) = -0.01066

Sequence 2 - {feature1 = 0} ==> {feature1 = 0 AND feature2 = 1}: S = {feature1 = 0} (Subset), N = 2 (# of all features), |S| = 1, |S|! = 1, apply Shapley Value formula
(|S|!*(N-|S|-1)!/N!)*(v(s+{feature2=1})-v(s)) = ((1!*(2-1-1)!)/2!)*( f(x) - E(f(z)|{feature1=0}) )
= 1/2*( f(x) - (Total log_odds of {feature1 = 0} / Total Frequency))
= 1/2*( (-0.36088) - (30427*(-0.3366)+16513*(-0.3609)) / (30427+16513) ) 
= 1/2*( (-0.36088) - (-0.34512) ) = -0.0079

So Shapley Value for {feature2 = 1} is: -0.01066+(-0.0079) = -0.01854

However this is slightly different from output form SHAP package (-0.0181). I followed the standard Shapley Value formula. What is causing the difference? Any insights or response would be appreciated! Thanks in advance!

Best Regards,
Wei
